question: What is the absolute difference in tens of thousands between the population of chinstrap penguins on the Wikipedia page for penguin species populations as of the end of 2018 and the population recorded in the Nature.com "global population assessment of the Chinstrap penguin" article from 2020, assuming two penguins per breeding pair?

trajectory.question: What is the absolute difference in tens of thousands between the population of chinstrap penguins on the Wikipedia page for penguin species populations as of the end of 2018 and the population recorded in the Nature.com "global population assessment of the Chinstrap penguin" article from 2020, assuming two penguins per breeding pair?

trajectory.actor_reasoning: I need to find the specific chinstrap population figures from the Wikipedia page and the Nature 2020 article to compute their difference.

1. A global population assessment of the Chinstrap penguin ...
   URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-76479-3
   Site: nature.com
   Summary: by N Strycker · 2020 · Cited by 76 — A global population assessment of the Chinstrap penguin (Pygoscelis antarctica) ... breeding pairs, and 12.5% had more than 10,000 breeding pairs.

Advertisement View all journals Search Log in Content Explore content About the journal Publish with us Sign up for alerts RSS feed nature scientific reports articles article A global population assessment of the Chinstrap penguin ( Pygoscelis antarctica ) Download PDF Download PDF Article Open access Published: 10 November 2020 A global population assessment of the Chinstrap penguin ( Pygoscelis antarctica ) Noah Strycker 1 , Michael Wethington 2 , Alex Borowicz 2 , Steve Forrest 2 , Chandi Witharana 3 , Tom Hart 4 & … Heather J. Lynch 2 , 5 Show authors Scientific Reports volume 10 , Article number: 19474 ( 2020 ) Cite this article 105k Accesses 60 Citations 67 Altmetric Metrics details Subjects Ecology Ocean sciences Abstract Using satellite imagery, drone imagery, and ground counts, we have assembled the first comprehensive global population assessment of Chinstrap penguins ( Pygoscelis antarctica ) at 3.42 (95th-percentile CI: [2.98, 4.00]) million breeding pairs across 375 extant colonies. Twenty-three previously known Chinstrap penguin colonies are found to be absent or extirpated. We identify five new colonies, and 21 additional colonies previously unreported and likely missed by previous surveys. Limited or imprecise historical data prohibit our assessment of population change at 35% of all Chinstrap penguin colonies. Of colonies for which a comparison can be made to historical counts in the 1980s, 45% have probably or certainly declined and 18% have probably or certainly in

Cárdenas 2 , 4 & … Lucas Krüger 2 , 4 Show authors Scientific Reports volume 13 , Article number: 5265 ( 2023 ) Cite this article 10k Accesses 13 Citations 60 Altmetric Metrics details Subjects Animal behaviour Behavioural ecology Marine biology Abstract Dramatic decreases of chinstrap penguin populations across the Antarctic Peninsula (AP) are thought to be influenced by climate-driven changes affecting its main prey, the Antarctic krill, however, empirical evidence supporting such hypotheses are scarce. By coupling data on breeding chinstrap penguins, environmental remote sensing and estimates of krill acoustic density, we were able to demonstrate that penguins substantially incre

   Summary: by O Belyaev · 2023 · Cited by 20 — Strycker, N. et al. A global population assessment of the Chinstrap penguin (Pygoscelis antarctica). Sci. Rep. 10, 19474 (2020). Article ADS ...

Advertisement View all journals Search Log in Content Explore content About the journal Publish with us Sign up for alerts RSS feed nature nature communications articles article The contribution of penguin guano to the Southern Ocean iron pool Download PDF Download PDF Article Open access Published: 11 April 2023 The contribution of penguin guano to the Southern Ocean iron pool Oleg Belyaev ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-8851-2996 1 , Erica Sparaventi ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-7578-8918 1 , Gabriel Navarro ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-8919-0060 1 , Araceli Rodríguez-Romero ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-6718-1040 2 & … Antonio Tovar-Sánchez 1 Show authors Nature Communications volume 14 , Article number: 1781 ( 2023 ) Cite this article 9476 Accesses 19 Citations 339 Altmetric Metrics details Subjects Element cycles Marine chemistry Abstract Iron plays a crucial role in the high-nutrient, low-chlorophyll Southern Ocean regions, promoting phytoplankton growth and enhancing atmospheric carbon sequestration. In this area, iron-rich Antarctic krill ( Euphausia superba ) and baleen whale species, which are among their main predators, play a large role in the recycling of iron. However, penguins have received limited attention despite their representing the largest seabird biomass in the southern polar region. Here, we use breeding site guano volumes estimated from drone images, deep learning-powered penguin census, and guano chemical composition to assess the iron export to the Antarctic waters from one of th

trajectory.actor_reasoning:
From Wikipedia: 8,000,000 chinstrap penguins (individuals).
From the 2020 Nature article: 3.42 million breeding pairs → 6,840,000 individuals (assuming two per pair).
Absolute difference: 8,000,000 − 6,840,000 = 1,160,000.
In tens of thousands: 1,160,000 ÷ 10,000 = 116.

FINAL ANSWER: 116

I need to find the specific chinstrap population figures from the Wikipedia page and the Nature 2020 article to compute their difference.

Advertisement View all journals Search Log in Content Explore content About the journal Publish with us Sign up for alerts RSS feed nature nature communications articles article The contribution of penguin guano to the Southern Ocean iron pool Download PDF Download PDF Article Open access Published: 11 April 2023 The contribution of penguin guano to the Southern Ocean iron pool Oleg Belyaev ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-8851-2996 1 , Erica Sparaventi ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-7578-8918 1 , Gabriel Navarro ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-8919-0060 1 , Araceli Rodríguez-Romero ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-6718-1040 2 & … Antonio Tovar-Sánchez 1 Show authors Nature Communications volume 14 , Article number: 1781 ( 2023 ) Cite this article 9476 Accesses 19 Citations 339 Altmetric Metrics details Subjects Element cycles Marine chemistry Abstract Iron plays a crucial role in the high-nutrient, low-chlorophyll Southern Ocean regions, promoting phytoplankton growth and enhancing atmospheric carbon sequestration. In this area, iron-rich Antarctic krill ( Euphausia superba ) and baleen whale species, which are among their main predators, play a large role in the recycling of iron. However, penguins have received limited attention despite their representing the largest seabird biomass in the southern polar region. Here, we use breeding site guano volumes estimated from drone images, deep learning-powered penguin census, and guano chemical composition to assess the iron export to the Antarctic waters from one of th
messages.name: enhanced_search

messages.content:
From Wikipedia: 8,000,000 chinstrap penguins (individuals).
From the 2020 Nature article: 3.42 million breeding pairs → 6,840,000 individuals (assuming two per pair).
Absolute difference: 8,000,000 − 6,840,000 = 1,160,000.
In tens of thousands: 1,160,000 ÷ 10,000 = 116.

FINAL ANSWER: 116
